sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Son of Cleinias, I think it must surprise you that I, the first of all your lovers, am the only one of them who has not given up his suit and thrown you over, and whereas they have all pestered you with their conversation I have not spoken one word to you for so many years. The cause of this has been nothing human, but a certain spiritual opposition,Socrates refers to the “spiritual sign” which occasionally warned him against an intended action: cf. Plat. Apol. 31c-d, Plat. Apol. 40a-b. of whose power you shall be informed at some later time. However, it now opposes me no longer, so I have accordingly come to you; and I am in good hopes that it will not oppose me again in the future. Now I have been observing you all this time, and have formed a pretty good notion of your behavior to your lovers: for although they were many and high-spirited, everyone of them has found your spirit too strong for him and has run away. Let me explain the reason of your spirit being too much for them. You say you have no need of any man in any matter; for your resources are so great, beginning with the body and ending with the soul, that you lack nothing. You think, in the first place, that you are foremost in beauty and stature—and you are not mistaken in this, as is plain for all to see—and in the second place, that you are of the most gallant family in your city, the greatest city in Greece, and that there you have, through your father, very many of the best people as your friends and kinsmen, who would assist you in case of need, and other connections also, through your mother, who are not a whit inferior to these, nor fewer. And you reckon upon a stronger power than all those that I have mentioned, in Pericles, son of Xanthippus, whom your father left as guardian of you and your brother when he died, and who is able to do whatever he likes not only in this city but all over Greece and among many great nations of the barbarians. And I will add besides the wealth of your house: but on this, I observe, you presume least of all. Well, you puff yourself up on all these advantages, and have overcome your lovers, while they in their inferiority have yielded to your might, and all this has not escaped you; so I am very sure that you wonder what on earth I mean by not getting rid of my passion, and what can be my hope in remaining when the rest have fled.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Perhaps also, Socrates, you are not aware that you have only just anticipated me. For I, in fact, had the intention of coming and asking you first that very same question—what is your aim and expectation in bothering me by making a particular point of always turning up wherever I may be. For I really do wonder what can be your object, and should be very glad if you would tell me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you will listen to me, presumably, with keen attention if, as you say, you long to know what I mean, and I have in you a listener who will stay to hear me out.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, to be sure: only speak.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Look to it, then; for it would be no wonder if I should make as much difficulty about stopping as I have made about starting.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: My good sir, speak; for I will listen.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Speak I must, I suppose. Now, although it is hard for a lover to parley with a man who does not yield to lovers, I must make bold nevertheless to put my meaning into words. For if I saw you, Alcibiades, content with the things I set forth just now, and minded to pass your life in enjoying them, I should long ago have put away my love, so at least I persuade myself: but as it is, I shall propound to your face quite another set of your thoughts, whereby you will understand that I have had you continually before my mind. For I believe, if some god should ask you: “Alcibiades, do you prefer to live with your present possessions, or to die immediately if you are not to have the chance of acquiring greater things?” I believe you would choose to die. But let me tell you what I imagine must be the present hope of your life. You think that if you come shortly before the Athenian Assembly—which you expect to occur in a very few days—you will stand forth and prove to the people that you are more worthy of honor than either Pericles or anyone else who has ever existed, and that having proved this you will have the greatest power in the state; and that if you are the greatest here, you will be the same among all the other Greeks, and not only Greeks, but all the barbarians who inhabit the same continent with us. And if that same god should say to you again, that you are to hold sway here in Europe, but are not to be allowed to cross over into Asia and to interfere with the affairs of that region, I believe you would be equally loth to live on those sole conditions either—if you are not to fill, one may say, the whole world with your name and your power; and I fancy that, except Cyrus and Xerxes, you think there has never existed a single man who was of any account. So then that this is your hope, I know well enough; I am not merely guessing. And I daresay you will reply, since you know that what I say is true: “Well, Socrates, and what has that to do with your point?” I am going to tell you, dear son of Cleinias and Deinomache. Without me it is impossible for all those designs of yours to be crowned with achievement; so great is the power I conceive myself to have over your affairs and over you, and it is for this very reason, I believe, that the god has so long prevented me from talking with you, and I was waiting to see when he would allow me. For as you have hopes of proving yourself in public to be invaluable to the state and, having proved it, of winning forthwith unlimited power, so do I hope to win supreme power over you by proving that I am invaluable to you, and that neither guardian nor kinsman nor anyone else is competent to transmit to you the power that you long for except me, with the god's help, however. In your younger days, to be sure, before you had built such high hopes, the god, as I believe, prevented me from talking with you, in order that I might not waste my words: but now he has set me on; for now you will listen to me.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You seem to me far more extraordinary, Socrates, now that you have begun to speak, than before, when you followed me about in silence; though even then you looked strange enough. Well, as to my intending all this or not, you have apparently made your decision, and any denial of mine will not avail me to persuade you. Very good: but supposing I have intended ever so much what you say, how are you the sole means through which I can hope to attain it? Can you tell me?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you asking whether I can make a long speech, such as you are used to hearing? No, my gift is not of that sort. But I fancy I could prove to you that the case is so, if you will consent to do me just one little service.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, if you mean a service that is not troublesome, I consent.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you consider it troublesome to answer questions put to you?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then answer.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Ask.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, you have the intentions which I say you have, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Be it so, if you like, in order that I may know what you will say next.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now then: you intend, as I say, to come forward as adviser to the Athenians in no great space of time; well, suppose I were to take hold of you as you were about to ascend the platform, and were to ask you: “Alcibiades, on what subject do the Athenians propose to take advice, that you should stand up to advise them? Is it something about which you have better knowledge than they?” What would be your reply?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I should say, I suppose, it was something about which I knew better than they.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you are a good adviser on things about which you actually know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you know only the things you have learnt from others or discovered yourself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What could I know besides?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can it be that you would ever have learnt or discovered anything without being willing either to learn it or to inquire into it yourself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, would you have been willing to inquire into or learn what you thought you knew?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So there was a time when you did not think that you knew what you now actually know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: There must have been.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, but I know pretty nearly the things that you have learnt: tell me if anything has escaped me. You learnt, if I recollect, writing and harping and wrestling; as for fluting, you refused to learn it. These are the things that you know, unless perhaps there is something you have been learning unobserved by me; and this you were not, I believe, if you so much as stepped out of doors either by night or by day.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I have taken no other lessons than those.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then tell me, will it be when the Athenians are taking advice how they are to do their writing correctly that you are to stand up and advise them?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Upon my word, not I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, about strokes on the lyre?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor in fact are they accustomed to deliberate on throws in wrestling either at the Assembly.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what will be the subject of the advice? For I presume it will not be about building.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For a builder will give better advice than you in that matter.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor yet will it be about divination?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For there again a diviner will serve better than you.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whether he be short or tall, handsome or ugly, nay, noble or ignoble.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For on each subject the advice comes from one who knows, not one who has riches.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And whether their mentor be poor or rich will make no difference to the Athenians when they deliberate for the health of the citizens; all that they require of their counsellor is that he be a physician.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Naturally.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what will they have under consideration if you are to be right in standing up, when you do so, as their counsellor?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Their own affairs, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean with regard to shipbuilding, and the question as to what sort of ships they ought to get built?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I do not, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because, I imagine, you do not understand shipbuilding. Is that, and that alone, the reason?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is just the reason.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, on what sort of affairs of their own do you mean that they will be deliberating?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: On war, Socrates, or on peace, or on any other of the state's affairs.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean that they will be deliberating with whom they ought to make peace, and on whom they ought to make war, and in what manner?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And on whom it is better to do so, ought they not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And at such time as it is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And for so long as they had better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now if the Athenians should deliberate with whom they should wrestle close, and with whom only at arm's length, and in what manner, would you or the wrestling-master be the better adviser?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The wrestling-master, I presume.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can you tell me what the wrestling-master would have in view when he advised as to the persons with whom they ought or ought not to wrestle close, and when and in what manner? What I mean is something like this: ought they not to wrestle close with those with whom it is better to do so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so far as is better, too?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So far.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And at such time also as is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But again, when one sings, one has sometimes to accompany the song with harping and stepping?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, one has.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And at such time as is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so far as is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, since you applied the term “better” to the two cases of harping for accompaniment of a song and close wrestling, what do you call the “better” in the case of harping, to correspond with what in the case of wrestling I call gymnastic? What do you call the other?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, try to copy me: for my answer gave you, I think, what is correct in every instance; and that is correct, I presume, which proceeds by rule of the art, is it not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And was not the art here gymnastic?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I said that the betterSocrates means by “better” or “the better way” the general method of attaining excellence in any art. in the case of wrestling was gymnastic.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You did.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I was quite fair?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, in your turn—for it would befit you also, I fancy, to argue fairlySocrates here repeats kalw=s (which means “handsomely” as well as “correctly”) in allusion to Alcibiades' good looks. Cf. Plat. Alc.1 113b—tell me, first, what is the art which includes harping and singing and treading the measure correctly? What is it called as a whole? You cannot yet tell me?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, try another way: who are the goddesses that foster the art?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The Muses, you mean, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I do. Now, just think, and say by what name the art is called after them.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Music,“Music” with the Greeks included poetry and dancing as well as our “music.” I suppose you mean.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I do. And what is that which proceeds correctly by its rule? As in the other case I was correct in mentioning to you gymnastic as that which goes by the art, so I ask you, accordingly, what you say in this case. What manner of proceeding is required?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: A musical one, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are right. Come then, what is it that you term “better,” in respect of what is better in waging war and being at peace? Just as in our other instances you said that the “better” implied the more musical and again, in the parallel case, the more gymnastical, try now if you can tell me what is the “better” in this case.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But I am quite unable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But surely that is disgraceful; for if you should speak to somebody as his adviser on food, and say that one sort was better than another, at this time and in this quantity, and he then asked you—What do you mean by the “better,” Alcibiades?—in a matter like that you could tell him you meant the more wholesome, although you do not set up to be a physician; yet in a case where you set up to have knowledge and are ready to stand up and advise as though you knew, are you not ashamed to be unable, as appears, to answer a question upon it? Does it not seem disgraceful?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then consider and do your best to tell me the connection of “better” in being at peace or at war with those to whom we ought to be so disposed.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, I am considering, but I fail to perceive it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you must know what treatment it is that we allege against each other when we enter upon a war, and what name we give it when we do so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do: we say we are victims of deceit or violence or spoliation.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Enough: how do we suffer each of these things? Try and tell me what difference there is between one way and another.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Do you mean by that, Socrates, whether it is in a just way or an unjust way?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, there you have all the difference in the world.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, on which sort are you going to advise the Athenians to make war—those who are acting unjustly, or those who are doing what is just?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is a hard question: for even if someone decides that he must go to war with those who are doing what is just, he would not admit that they were doing so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For that would not be lawful, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed; nor is it considered honorable either.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you too will appeal to these things in making your speeches?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then must not that “better” about which I was asking in reference to making or not making war, on those on whom we ought to or not, and when we ought to or not, be simply and solely the juster?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How now, friend Alcibiades? Have you overlooked your own ignorance of this matter, or have I overlookedCf. above, Plat. Alc.1 106e. your learning it and taking lessons of a master who taught you to distinguish the more just and the more unjust? And who is he? Inform me in my turn, in order that you may introduce me to him as another pupil.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You are joking, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, I swear by our common God of Friendship, whose name I would by no means take in vain. Come, if you can, tell me who the man is.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But what if I cannot? Do you think I could not know about what is just and unjust in any other way?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, you might, supposing you discovered it.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But do you not think I might discover it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, quite so, if you inquired.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And do you not think I might inquire?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I do, if you thought you did not know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And was there not a time when I held that view?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well spoken. Then can you tell me at what time it was that you thought you did not know what is just and unjust? Pray, was it a year ago that you were inquiring, and thought you did not know? Or did you think you knew? Please answer truly, that our debates may not be futile.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, I thought I knew.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And two years, and three years, and four years back, were you not of the same mind?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, you see, before that time you were a child, were you not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So I know well enough that then you thought you knew.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you know it so well?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Many a time I heard you, when as a child you were dicing or playing some other game at your teacher's or elsewhere, instead of showing hesitation about what was just and unjust, speak in very loud and confident tones about one or other of your playmates, saying he was a rascal and a cheat who played unfairly. Is not this a true account?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But what was I to do, Socrates, when somebody cheated me?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yet if you were ignorant then whether you were being unfairly treated or not, how can you ask—“What are you to do?”

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, but on my word, I was not ignorant: no, I clearly understood that I was being wronged.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you thought you knew, even as a child, it seems, what was just and unjust.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I did; and I knew too.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: At what sort of time did you discover it? For surely it was not while you thought you knew.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then when did you think you were ignorant? Consider; I believe you will fail to find such a time.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Upon my word, Socrates, I really cannot say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you do not know it by discovery.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Not at all, apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you said just now that you did not know it by learning either; and if you neither discovered nor learnt it, how do you come to know it, and whence?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, perhaps that answer I gave you was not correct, that I knew it by my own discovery.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then how was it done?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I learnt it, I suppose, in the same way as everyone else.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Back we come to the same argument. From whom? Please tell me.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: From the many.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: They are no very serious teachers with whom you take refuge, if you ascribe it to the many!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, are they not competent to teach?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not how to play, or not to play, draughts; and yet that, I imagine, is a slight matter compared with justice. What? Do you not think so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if they are unable to teach the slighter, can they teach the more serious matter?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so: at any rate, there are many other things that they are able to teach, more serious than draughts.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What sort of things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: For instance, it was from them that I learnt to speak Greek, and I could not say who was my teacher, but can only ascribe it to the same people who, you say, are not serious teachers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Ah, gallant sir, the many may be good teachers of that, and they can justly be praised for their teaching of such subjects.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because in those subjects they have the equipment proper to good teachers.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You know that those who are going to teach anything should first know it themselves, do you not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that those who know should agree with each other and not differ?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if they differ upon anything, will you say that they know it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then how can they be teachers of it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, do you find that the many differ about the nature of stone or wood? If you ask one of them, do they not agree on the same answer, and make for the same things when they want to get a piece of stone or wood? It is just the same, too, with everything of the sort: for I am pretty nearly right in understanding you to mean just this by knowing how to speak Greek, am I not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And on these matters, as we stated, they not only agree with each other and with themselves in private, but states also use in public the same terms about them to each other, without any dispute?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: They do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then naturally they will be good teachers of these matters.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if we should wish to provide anyone with knowledge of them, we should be right in sending him to be taught by “the many” that you speak of?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But what if we wished to know not only what men were like or what horses were like, but which of them were good runners or not? Would the many still suffice to teach us this?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you have ample proof that they do not know this, and are not proficient teachers of it, in their not agreeing about it at all with themselves?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if we wished to know not only what men were like, but what healthy or diseased men were like? Would the many suffice to teach us?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you would have proof of their being bad teachers of that, if you saw them differing about it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I should.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, do you now find that the many agree with themselves or each other about just and unjust men or things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Far from it, on my word, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In fact, they differ most especially on these points?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I suppose you never yet saw or heard of people differing so sharply on questions of health or the opposite as to fight and kill one another in battle because of them.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But on questions of justice or injustice I am sure you have; and if you have not seen them, at any rate you have heard of them of Plato. the Odyssey and the Iliad?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I certainly have, I suppose, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And these poems are about a difference of just and unjust

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And from this difference arose the fights and deaths of the Achaeans, and of the Trojans as well, and of the suitors of Penelope in their strife with Odysseus.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I imagine that when the Athenians and Spartans and Boeotians lost their men at Tanagra,457 B.C. and later at Coronea,447 B.C. among whom your own father perished, the difference that caused their deaths and fights was solely on a question of just and unjust, was it not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then are we to say that these people understand those questions, on which they differ so sharply that they are led by their mutual disputes to take these extreme measures against each other?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you refer me to teachers of that sort, whom you admit yourself to be without knowledge?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then how is it likely that you should know what is just and unjust, when you are so bewildered about these matters and are shown to have neither learnt them from anyone nor discovered them for yourself?.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By what you say, it is not likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There again, Alcibiades, do you see how unfairly you speak?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: In what ?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In stating that I say so.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, do you not say that l do not know about the just and unjust?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, do I say it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How, pray ?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will show you, in the following way. If I ask you which is the greater number, one or two, you will answer “two”?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, I shall.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How much greater?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By one.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then which of us says that two are one more than one?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I was asking, and you were answering?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is it I, the questioner, or you the answerer, that are found to be speaking about these things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if I ask what are the letters in “Socrates,” and you tell me? Which will be the speaker?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, tell me, as a principle, when we have question and answer, which is the speaker—the questioner, or the answerer?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The answerer, I should say, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And throughout the argument so far, I was the questioner?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you the answerer?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, which of us has spoken what has been said?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently, Socrates, from what we have admitted, it was I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it was said that Alcibiades, the fair son of Cleinias, did not know about just and unjust, but thought he did, and intended to go to the Assembly as adviser to the Athenians on what he knows nothing about; is not that so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
Then, to quote Euripides,Eur. Hipp. 352—sou= ta/d', ou)k e)mou= klu/eis. the result is, Alcibiades, that you may be said to have
heard it from yourself, not me,Eur. Hipp. 352 and it is not I who say it, but you, and you tax me with it in vain. And indeed what you say is quite true. For it is a mad scheme this, that you meditate, my excellent friend—of teaching things that you do not know, since you have taken no care to learn them.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think, Socrates, that the Athenians and the rest of the Greeks rarely deliberate as to which is the more just or unjust course: for they regard questions of this sort as obvious; and so they pass them over and consider which course will prove more expedient in the result. For the just and the expedient, I take it, are not the same, but many people have profited by great wrongs that they have committed, whilst others, I imagine, have had no advantage from doing what was right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What then? Granting that the just and the expedient are in fact as different as they can be, you surely do not still suppose you know what is expedient for mankind, and why it is so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, what is the obstacle, Socrates,—unless you are going to ask me again from whom I learnt it, or how I discovered it for myself?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What a way of going on! If your answer is incorrect, and a previous argument can be used to prove it so, you claim to be told something new, and a different line of proof, as though the previous one were like a poor worn-out coat which you refuse to wear any longer; you must be provided instead with something clean and unsoiled in the way of evidence. But I shall ignore your sallies in debate, and shall none the less ask you once more, where you learnt your knowledge of what is expedient, and who is your teacher, asking in one question all the things I asked before; and now you will clearly find yourself in the same plight, and will be unable to prove that you know the expedient either through discovery or through learning. But as you are dainty, and would dislike a repeated taste of the same argument, I pass over this question of whether you know or do not know what is expedient for the Athenians: but why have you not made it clear whether the just and the expedient are the same or different? If you like, question me as I did you, or if you prefer, argue out the matter in your own way.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But I am not sure I should be able, Socrates, to set it forth to you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, my good sir, imagine I am the people in Assembly; even there, you know, you will have to persuade each man singly, will you not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the same man may well persuade one person singly, and many together, about things that he knows, just as the schoolmaster, I suppose, persuades either one or many about letters?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, will not the same man persuade either one or many about number?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And this will be the man who knows—the arithmetician?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you too can persuade a single man about things of which you can persuade many?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Presumably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And these are clearly things that you know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the only difference between the orator speaking before the people and one who speaks in a conversation like ours is that the former persuades men in a number together of the same things, and the latter persuades them one at a time?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It looks like it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come now, since we see that the same man may persuade either many or one, try your unpracticed hand on me, and endeavor to show that the just is sometimes not expedient.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You are insolent, Socrates!

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This time, at any rate, I am going to have the insolence to persuade you of the opposite of that which you decline to prove to me.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Speak, then.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Just answer my questions.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, you yourself must be the speaker.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What? Do you not wish above all things to be persuaded?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By all means, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you would best be persuaded if you should say “the case is so”?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then answer; and if you do not hear your own self say that the just is expedient, put no trust in the words of anyone again.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I will not: but I may as well answer; for I do not think I shall come to any harm.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are quite a prophet! Now tell me, do you consider some just things to be expedient, and others not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, some noble, and some not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What do you mean by that question?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I would ask whether anyone ever seemed to you to be doing what was base and yet just.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, are all just things noble?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what of noble things, in their turn? Are they all good, or some only, while others are not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: In my opinion, Socrates, some noble things are evil.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And some base things are good?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean as in one of the many cases where men have gone to rescue a comrade or kinsman in battle, and have been either wounded or killed, while those who did not go to the rescue, as duty bade, have got off safe and sound?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And such a rescue you call noble, in respect of the endeavor to save those whom it was one's duty to save; and this is courage, is it not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you call it evil, in respect of the deaths and wounds?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not the courage one thing, and the death another?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is not in the same respect that rescuing one's friends is noble and evil?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then see if, inasmuch as it is noble, it is also good; for in the present case you were admitting that the rescue was noble in respect of its courage: now consider this very thing, courage, and say whether it is good or bad. Consider it in this way: which would you choose to have, good things or evil?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And most of all, the greatest goods, and of such things you would least allow yourself to be deprived?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what do you say of courage? At what price would you allow yourself to be deprived of it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I would give up life itself if I had to be a coward.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you regard cowardice as the uttermost evil.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: On a par with death, it seems.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And life and courage are the extreme opposites of death and cowardice?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you would most desire to have the former, and least the latter?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is that because you think the former best, and the latter worst?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you reckon courage among the best things, and death among the worst.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the rescue of one's friends in battle, inasmuch as it is noble in respect of the working of good by courage, you have termed noble?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But evil, in respect of the working of evil by death?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So we may fairly describe each of these workings as follows: as you call either of them evil because of the evil it produces, so you must call it good because of the good it produces.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I believe that is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again, are they noble inasmuch as they are good, and base inasmuch as they are evil?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then in saying that the rescue of one's friends in battle is noble and yet evil, you mean just the same as if you called the rescue good, but evil.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I believe what you say is true, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So nothing noble, in so far as it is noble, is evil, and nothing base, in so far as it is base, is good.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now then, consider it again in this way: whoever does nobly, does well too, does he not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are not those who do well happy?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And they are happy because of the acquisition of good things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And they acquire these by doing well and nobly?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So doing well is good?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And welfare is noble?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence we have seen again that noble and good are the same thing.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whatever we find to be noble we shall find also to be good, by this argument at least.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, are good things expedient or not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Expedient.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you remember what our admissions were about just things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think we said that those who do just things must do noble things.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that those who do noble things must do good things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that good things are expedient?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence just things, Alcibiades, are expedient.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, are not you the speaker of all this, and I the questioner?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I seem to be, apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So if anyone stands up to advise either the Athenians or the Peparethians,Peparethus is a small island off the coast of Thessaly. imagining that he understands what is just and unjust, and says that just things are sometimes evil, could you do other than laugh him to scorn, since you actually say yourself that just and expedient are the same?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But by Heaven, Socrates, I do not even know what I am saying, I feel altogether in such a strange state! For from moment to moment I change my view under your questioning.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are you unaware, my friend, what this feeling is?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I am, quite.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do you suppose that if someone should ask you whether you have two eyes or three, two hands or four, or anything else of that sort, you would answer differently from moment to moment, or always the same thing?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I begin to have misgivings about myself, but still I think I should make the same answer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the reason would be, because you know?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if you involuntarily give contradictory answers, clearly it must be about things of which you are ignorant.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you say you are bewildered in answering about just and unjust, noble and base, evil and good, expedient and inexpedient? Now, is it not obvious that your bewilderment is caused by your ignorance of these things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is it the case that when a man does not know a thing he must needs be bewildered in spirit regarding that thing?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, do you know in what way you can ascend to heaven?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: On my word, not I.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is that too a kind of question about which your judgement is bewildered?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you know the reason, or shall I state it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: State it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is, my friend, that while not knowing the matter you do not suppose that you know it.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Here again, how do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do your share, in seeing for yourself. Are you bewildered about the kind of thing that you do not know and are aware of not knowing? For instance, you know, I suppose, that you do not know about the preparation of a tasty dish?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you think for yourself how you are to prepare it, and get bewildered, or do you entrust it to the person who knows?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do the latter.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if you should be on a ship at sea? Would you think whether the tiller should be moved inwards or outwards,The “tiller” was the handle of an oar at the side of the stern, and was moved towards or away from the center of the ship. and in your ignorance bewilder yourself, or would you entrust it to the helmsman, and be quiet?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I would leave it to him.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you are not bewildered about what you do not know, so long as you know that you do not know?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems I am not,

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you note that mistakes in action also are due to this ignorance of thinking one knows when one does not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Here again, how do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We set about acting, I suppose, when we think we know what we are doing?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But when people think they do not know, I suppose they hand it over to others?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so that kind of ignorant person makes no mistakes in life, because they entrust such matters to others?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Who then are those who make mistakes? For, I take it, they cannot be those who know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But since it is neither those who know, nor those of the ignorant who know that they do not know, the only people left, I think, are those who do not know, but think that they do?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, only those.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this ignorance is a cause of evils, and is the discreditable sort of stupidity?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when it is about the greatest matters, it is most injurious and base?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By far.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, can you mention any greater things than the just, the noble, the good, and the expedient?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is about these, you say, that you are bewildered?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if you are bewildered, is it not clear from what has gone before that you are not only ignorant of the greatest things, but while not knowing them you think that you do?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I am afraid so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Alack then, Alcibiades, for the plight you are in! I shrink indeed from giving it a name, but still, as we are alone, let me speak out. You are wedded to stupidity, my fine friend, of the vilest kind; you are impeached of this by your own words, out of your own mouth; and this, it seems, is why you dash into politics before you have been educated. And you are not alone in this plight, but you share it with most of those who manage our city's affairs, except just a few, and perhaps your guardian, Pericles.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, you know, Socrates, they say he did not get his wisdom independently, but consorted with many wise men, such as PythocleidesA musician of Ceos (who was perhaps also a Pythagorean philosopher) who taught in Athens. and AnaxagorasAn Ionian philosopher who lived in Athens c. 480-430 B.C.; and now, old as he is, he still confers with DamonAn Athenian musician and sophist. for that very purpose.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, but did you ever find a man who was wise in anything and yet unable to make another man wise in the same things as himself? For instance, the man who taught you letters was wise himself, and also made you wise, and anyone else he wished to, did he not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you too, who learnt from him, will be able to make another man wise?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the same holds of the harper and the trainer?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For, I presume, it is a fine proof of one's knowing anything that one knows, when one is able to point to another man whom one has made to know it.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, can you tell me whom Pericles made wise? One of his sons, to begin with?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But what if the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, Cleinias, your brother.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But why should you mention Cleinias, a madman?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, if Cleinias is mad and the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, what reason are we to assign, in your case, for his allowing you to be in your present condition?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I believe I am myself to blame for not attending to him.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But tell me of any other Athenian or foreigner, slave or freeman, who is accounted to have become wiser through converse with Pericles; as I can tell you that PythodorusA friend of Zeno: cf. Plat. Parm. 126. son of Isolochus, and Callias,An Athenian general. son of Calliades, became through that of ZenoOf Elea, in S. Italy; a disciple of Parmenides who criticized the Pythagorean teaching.; each of them has paid Zeno a hundred minae,About 600-800 pounds, or the total expenses of two or three years at an English University. and has become both wise and distinguished.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, upon my word, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very good: then what is your intention regarding yourself? Will you remain as you are, or take some trouble?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We must put our heads together, Socrates. And indeed, as soon as you speak, I take the point and agree. For the men who manage the city's affairs, apart from a few, do strike me as uneducated.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what does that mean?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That if they were educated, I suppose anyone who undertook to contend against them would have to get some knowledge and practice first, as he would for a match with athletes: but now, seeing that these men have gone in for politics as amateurs, what need is there for me to practise and have the trouble of learning? For I am sure that my natural powers alone will give me an easy victory over them.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Ho, ho, my good sir, what a thing to say! How unworthy of your looks and your other advantages!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is your meaning now, Socrates? What is the connection?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I am grieved for you, and for my love.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, pray?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That you should expect your contest to be with the men we have here.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, but with whom is it to be?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is that a worthy question to be asked by a man who considers himself high-spirited?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you mean? Is not my contest with these men?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, suppose you were intending to steer a warship into action, would you be content to be the best hand among the crew at steering or, while regarding this skill as a necessary qualification, would you keep your eye on your actual opponents in the fight, and not, as now, on your fellow-fighters? These, I conceive, you ought so far to surpass that they would not feel fit to be your opponents, but only to be your despised fellow-fighters against the enemy, if you mean really to make your mark with some noble action that will be worthy both of yourself and of the city.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, I do mean to.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So you think it quite fitting for you to be satisfied if you are better than the soldiers, but neglect to keep your eye on the enemy's leaders with a view to showing yourself better than they are, or to plan and practise against them!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of whom are you speaking now, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you not know that our city makes war occasionally on the Spartans and on the Great King?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if you are minded to be the head of our state, you would be right in thinking that your contest is with the kings of Sparta and of Persia?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That sounds like the truth.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, my good friend; you ought rather to keep your eye on Meidias the quail-filliperMeidias is mentioned by Aristophanes (Aristoph. Birds 1297) for his skill in the game of filliping quails which were specially trained not to flinch. and others of his sort—who undertake to manage the city's affairs, while they still have the slavish hairSlaves in Athens were largely natives of western Asia. and had thick, close hair, very different from the wavy locks of the Greeks. (as the women would say) showing in their minds through their lack of culture, and have not yet got rid of it; who, moreover, have come with their outlandish speech to flatter the state, not to rule it—to these, I tell you, should your eyes be turned; and then you can disregard yourself, and need neither learn what is to be learnt for the great contest in which you are to be engaged, nor practise what requires practice, and so ensure that you are perfectly prepared before entering upon a political career.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, Socrates, I believe you are right; though I think neither the Spartan generals nor the Persian king are at all different from other people.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, my excellent friend, consider what this notion of yours means.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: In regard to what?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First of all, do you think you would take more pains over yourself if you feared them and thought them terrible, or if you did not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly, if I thought them terrible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you think you will come to any harm by taking pains over yourself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By no means; rather that I shall get much benefit.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And on this single count that notioni.e. about the Spartan generals and the Persian king, Plat. Alc.1 120c. of yours is so much to the bad.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, in the second place, observe the probability that it is false.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is it probable that noble races should produce better natures, or not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly, noble races would.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And will not the well-born, provided they are well brought up, probably be perfected in virtue?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That must be so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us consider, by comparing our lot with theirs, whether the Spartan and Persian kings appear to be of inferior birth. Do we not know that the former are descendants of Hercules and the latter of Achaemenes, and that the line of Hercules and the line of Achaemenes go back to Perseus, son of Zeus?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, and mine, Socrates, to Eurysaces, and that of Eurysaces to Zeus!

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, and mine, noble Alcibiades, to Daedalus,Socrates' father, Sophroniscus, was a sculptor, and Daedalus was the legendary inventor of sculpture. and Daedalus to Hephaestus, son of Zeus! But take the lines of those people,i.e., the kings of Sparta and Persia. going back from them: you have a succession of kings reaching to Zeus—on the one hand, kings of Argos and Sparta; on the other, of Persia, which they have always ruled, and frequently Asia also, as at present; whereas we are private persons ourselves, and so were our fathers. And then, suppose that you had to make what show you could of your ancestors, and of Salamis as the native land of Eurysaces, or of Aegina as the home of the yet earlier Aeacus, to impress Artaxerxes, son of Xerxes, how you must expect to be laughed at! Why, I am afraid we are quite outdone by those persons in pride of birth and upbringing altogether. Or have you not observed how great are the advantages of the Spartan kings, and how their wives are kept under statutory ward of the ephors, in order that every possible precaution may be taken against the king being born of any but the Heracleidae? And the Persian king so far surpasses us that no one has a suspicion that he could have been born of anybody but the king before him; and hence the king's wife has nothing to guard her except fear. When the eldest son, the heir to the throne, is born, first of all the king's subjects who are in his palace have a feast, and then for ever after on that date the whole of Asia celebrates the king's birthday with sacrifice and feasting: but when we are born, as the comic poetThe saying, which became proverbial, is thought to have occurred in one of the (now lost) plays of Plato, the Athenian comic poet, who lived c. 460-389 B.C. says, even the neighbors barely notice it,Plato Comicus? Alcibiades. After that comes the nurture of the child, not at the hands of a woman-nurse of little worth, but of the most highly approved eunuchs in the king's service, who are charged with the whole tendance of the new-born child, and especially with the business of making him as handsome as possible by moulding his limbs into a correct shape; and while doing this they are in high honor. When the boys are seven years old they are given horses and have riding lessons, and they begin to follow the chase. And when the boy reaches fourteen years he is taken over by the royal tutors, as they call them there: these are four men chosen as the most highly esteemed among the Persians of mature age, namely, the wisest one, the justest one, the most temperate one, and the bravest one. The first of these teaches him the magian lore of Zoroaster,Zoroaster was the reputed founder of the Persian religion, of which the ministers were the Magi or hereditary priests. son of Horomazes; and that is the worship of the gods: he teaches him also what pertains to a king. The justest teaches him to be truthful all his life long; the most temperate, not to be mastered by even a single pleasure, in order that he may be accustomed to be a free man and a veritable king, who is the master first of all that is in him, not the slave; while the bravest trains him to be fearless and undaunted, telling him that to be daunted is to be enslaved. But you, Alcibiades, had a tutor set over you by Pericles from amongst his servants,who was old as to be the most useless of them, Zopyrus the Thracian. I might describe to you at length the nurture and education of your competitors, were it not too much of a task; and besides, what I have said suffices to show the rest that follows thereon. But about your birth, Alcibiades, or nurture or education, or about those of any other Athenian, one may say that nobody cares, unless it be some lover whom you chance to have. And again, if you chose to glance at the wealth, the luxury, the robes with sweeping trains, the anointings with myrrh, the attendant troops of menials, and all the other refinements of the Persians, you would be ashamed at your own case, on perceiving its inferiority to theirs. Should you choose, again, to look at the temperance and orderliness, the facility and placidity, the magnanimity and discipline, the courage and endurance, and the toil-loving, success-loving, honor-loving spirit of the Spartans, you would count yourself but a child in all these things. If again you regard wealth, and think yourself something in that way, I must not keep silence on this point either, if you are to realize where you stand. For in this respect you have only to look at the wealth of the Spartans, and you will perceive that our riches here are far inferior to theirs. Think of all the land that they have both in their own and in the Messenian country: not one of our estates could compete with theirs in extent and excellence, nor again in ownership of slaves, and especially of those of the helot class, nor yet of horses, nor of all the flocks and herds that graze in Messene. However, I pass over all these things: but there is more gold and silver privately held in Lacedaemon than in the whole of Greece; for during many generations treasure has been passing in to them from every part of Greece, and often from the barbarians also, but not passing out to anyone; and just as in the fable of Aesop, where the fox remarked to the lion on the direction of the footmarks, the traces of the money going into Lacedaemon are clear enough, but nowhere are any to be seen of it coming out; so that one can be pretty sure that those people are the richest of the Greeks in gold and silver, and that among themselves the richest is the king; for the largest and most numerous receipts of the kind are those of the kings, and besides there is the levy of the royal tribute in no slight amount, which the Spartans pay to their kings. Now, the Spartan fortunes, though great compared with the wealth of other Greeks, are nought beside that of the Persians and their king. For I myself was once told by a trustworthy person, who had been up to their court, that he traversed a very large tract of excellent land, nearly a day's journey, which the inhabitants called the girdle of the king's wife, and another which was similarly called her veil; and many other fine and fertile regions reserved for the adornment of the consort; and each of these regions was named after some part of her apparel. So I imagine, if someone should say to the king's mother Amestris, who was wife of Xerxes, “The son of DeinomacheThe mother of Alcibiades. intends to challenge your son; the mother's dresses are worth perhaps fifty minae at the outside, while the son has under three hundred acres at Erchiae,In Attica, about fifteen miles east of Athens.” she would wonder to what on earth this Alcibiades could be trusting, that he proposed to contend against Artaxerxes; and I expect she would remark—“The only possible things that the man can be trusting to for his enterprise are industry and wisdom; for these are the only things of any account among the Greeks.” Whereas if she were informed that this Alcibiades who is actually making such an attempt is, in the first place, as yet barely twenty years old, and secondly, altogether uneducated; and further, that when his lover tells him that he must first learn, and take pains over himself, and practise, before he enters on a contest with the king, he refuses, and says he will do very well as he is; I expect she would ask in surprise, “On what, then, can the youngster rely?” And if we told her, “On beauty, stature, birth, wealth, and mental gifts,” she would conclude we were mad, Alcibiades, when she compared the advantages of her own people in all these respects. And I imagine that even Lampido, daughter of Leotychides and wife of Archidamus and mother of Agis, who have all been kings, would wonder in the same way, when she compared her people's resources, at your intention of having a contest with her son despite your bad upbringing. And yet, does it not strike you as disgraceful that our enemies' wives should have a better idea of the qualities that we need for an attempt against them than we have ourselves? Ah, my remarkable friend, listen to me and the Delphic motto, “Know thyself”; for these people are our competitors, not those whom you think; and there is nothing that will give us ascendancy over them save only pains and skill. If you are found wanting in these, you will be found wanting also in achievement of renown among Greeks and barbarians both; and of this I observe you to be more enamored than anyone else ever was of anything.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well then, what are the pains that I must take, Socrates? Can you enlighten me? For I must say your words are remarkably like the truth.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, I can: but we must put our heads together,Cf. above, Plat. Alc. 1.119b. you know, as to the way in which we can improve ourselves to the utmost. For observe that when I speak of the need of being educated I am not referring only to you, apart from myself; since my case is identical with yours except in one point.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My guardian is better and wiser than your one, Pericles.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Who is he, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: God, Alcibiades, who until this day would not let me converse with you; and trusting in him I say that through no other man but me will you attain to eminence.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You are jesting, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps; I am right, however, in saying that we need to take pains—all men rather badly, but we two very badly indeed.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: As to me, you are not wrong.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor, I fear, as to myself either.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Then what can we do?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There must be no crying off or skulking, my good friend.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, for that would indeed be unseemly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It would; so let us consider in common. Now tell me: we say, do we not, that we wish to be as good as possible?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In what excellence?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly that which is the aim of good men.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Good in what?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly, good in the management of affairs.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What sort of affairs? Horsemanship?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because we should apply to horsemen?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, seamanship, do you mean?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because we should apply to seamen?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, what sort of thing? The business of what men?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of Athenian gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you mean by “gentlemen” the intelligent or the unintelligent?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The intelligent.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And everyone is good in that wherein he is intelligent?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And bad wherein he is unintelligent?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then is the shoemaker intelligent in the making of foot-gear?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he is good in that article?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, is not the shoemaker unintelligent in the making of clothes?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he is bad in that?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, on this showing, the same man is both bad and good.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, can you say that good men are also bad?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But whoever do you mean by the good?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I mean those who are able to rule in the city.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Not, I presume, over horses?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But over men?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When they are sick?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or at sea?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I say, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or harvesting?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Doing nothing, or doing something?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Doing something, I say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Doing what? Try and let me know.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, men who do business with each other and make use of one another, as is our way of life in our cities.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you speak of ruling over men who make use of men?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Over boatswains who make use of rowers?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because that is the pilot's distinction?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do you mean ruling over men who are flute-players, and who lead the singing and make use of dancers?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because, again, that is the chorus-teacher's function?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But whatever do you mean by being able to rule over men who make use of men?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I mean ruling over men in the city who share in it as fellow-citizens, and do business with each other.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, what art is this? Suppose I should ask you over again, as I did just now, what art makes men know how to rule over fellow-sailors?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: The pilot's.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what knowledge—to repeat what was said a moment ago—makes them rule over their fellow-singers?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That which you just mentioned, the chorus-teacher's.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, what do you call the knowledge of one's fellow-citizens?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Good counsel, I should say, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and is the pilot's knowledge evil counsel?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Rather good counsel?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So I should think, for the preservation of his passengers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Quite right. And now, for what is the good counsel of which you speak?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: For the better management and preservation of the city.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what is it that becomes present or absent when we get this better management and preservation? If, for example, you should ask me, “What is it that becomes present or absent when the body is better managed and preserved?”—I should reply, “Health becomes present, and disease absent.” Do not you think so too?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if, again, you asked me, “What becomes present in a better condition of the eyes?”—I should answer in just the same way, “Sight becomes present, and blindness absent.” So, in the case of the ears, deafness is caused to be absent, and hearing to be present, when they are improved and getting better treatment.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, what is it that becomes present or absent when a state is improved and has better treatment and management?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To my mind, Socrates, friendship with one another will be there, while hatred and faction will be absent.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, by friendship do you mean agreement or disagreement?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Agreement.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what art is it that causes states to agree about numbers?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Arithmetic.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what of individuals? Is it not the same art?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it makes each single person agree with himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what art makes each of us agree with himself as to which is the longer, a span or a cubit? Is it not mensuration?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it makes both individuals and states agree with each other?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what about the balance? Is it not the same here too?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what is that agreement of which you speak, and about what? And what art secures it? And is it the same in an individual as in a state, when one agrees with oneself and with another?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Most likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, what is it? Do not flag in your answers, but do your best to tell me.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I suppose I mean the friendship and agreement that you find when a father and mother love their son, and between brother and brother, and husband and wife.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you suppose, Alcibiades, that a husband can possibly agree with his wife about woolwork, when he does not understand it, and she does?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor has he any need, since that is a woman's pursuit.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or again, could a woman agree with a man about soldiering, when she has not learnt it?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because, I expect you will say again, that is a man's affair.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I would.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, by your account, there are some pursuits belonging to women, and some to men?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So in these, at any rate, there is no agreement between men and women.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And hence no friendship either, if, as we said, friendship is agreement.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So women are not loved by men, in so far as they do their own work.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor are men by women, in so far as they do theirs.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And states, therefore, are not well ordered in so far as each person does his own business?Cf. Plat. Charm. 161e, Plat. Rep. 1.332 ff.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think they are, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How can you say that? Without the presence of friendship, which we say must be there if states are well ordered, as otherwise they are not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: But it seems to me that friendship arises among them just on that account—that each of the two parties does its own business.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It was not so a moment since: but now, what do you mean this time? Does friendship arise where there is no agreement? And is it possible that agreement should arise where some know about the business, but others do not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are they doing what is just or unjust, when each man does his own business?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is just, of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when the citizens do what is just in the city, does not friendship arise among them?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Again I think that must be so, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whatever do you mean by that friendship or agreement about which we must be wise and well-advised in order that we may be good men? For I am unable to learn either what it is, or in whom; since it appears that the same persons sometimes have it, and sometimes not, by your account.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, by Heaven, Socrates, I do not even know what I mean myself, and I fear that for some time past I have lived unawares in a disgraceful condition.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But you must take heart. For had you perceived your plight at fifty, it would be hard for you to take pains with yourself; whereas here you are at the time of life when one ought to perceive it.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Then what should one do on perceiving it, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Answer the questions asked, Alcibiades: only do that, and with Heaven's favor—if we are to put any trust in my divination—you and I shall both be in better case.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That shall be, so far as my answering can avail.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, what is “taking pains over oneself”— for we may perchance be taking, unawares, no pains over ourselves, though we think we are—and when does a man actually do it? Does he take pains over himself at the same time as over his own things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I at least believe so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, when does a man take pains over his feet? Is it when he takes pains over what belongs to his feet?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is there anything you can name as belonging to the hand? For instance, does a ring belong to any other part of a man but the finger?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so the shoe also belongs to the foot, in the same way?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And likewise clothes and coverlets belong to the whole body?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now when we take pains over our shoes, we take pains over our feet?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do not quite understand, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, but, Alcibiades, you speak of taking proper pains over this or that matter, do you not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you call it proper pains when someone makes a thing better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what art makes shoes better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Shoe-making.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So by shoe-making we take pains over our shoes?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And over our foot too by shoe-making? Or by that art whereby we make feet better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By that art.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is it not the same one for making our feet as for making the whole body better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is not that gymnastic?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So by gymnastic we take pains over our foot, but by shoe-making over what belongs to our foot?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And by gymnastic over our hands, but by ring-engraving over what belongs to the hand?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And by gymnastic over the body, but by weaving and the rest over what belongs to the body?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Absolutely so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then for taking pains over a thing itself and over what belongs to it we use different arts.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So when you take pains over your belongings you are not taking pains over yourself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For the arts, it seems, that one used for taking pains over oneself and over one's belongings would not be the same.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, whatever kind of art can we use for taking pains over ourselves?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, so much at least has been admitted, that it is not one which would help us to make a single one of our possessions better, but one which would help to make ourselves so?
