sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, should we ever have known what art makes a shoe better, if we had not known a shoe?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor could we know what art makes rings better, if we had no cognizance of a ring.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, could we ever know what art makes the man himself better, if we were ignorant of what we are ourselves?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and is it an easy thing to know oneself, and was it a mere scamp who inscribed these words on the temple at Delphi; or is it a hard thing, and not a task for anybody?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I have often thought, Socrates, that it was for anybody; but often, too, that it was very hard.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, Alcibiades, whether it is easy or not, here is the fact for us all the same: if we have that knowledge, we are like to know what pains to take over ourselves; but if we have it not, we never can.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Come then, in what way can the same-in-itselfThis seems to be a sudden adumbration of the Platonic “idea” or form which remains constant, and so “the same,” behind the shifting objects of sense related to it through its influences or impress. Cf. below, Plat. Alc. 1.130d. be discovered? For thus we may discover what we are ourselves; whereas if we remain in ignorance of it we must surely fail.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Rightly spoken.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Steady, then, in Heaven's name! To whom are you talking now? To me, are you not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I in turn to you ?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the talker is Socrates?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the hearer, Alcibiades?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And Socrates uses speech in talking?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you call talking and using speech the same thing, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the user and the thing he uses are different, are they not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For instance, I suppose a shoemaker uses a round tool, and a square one, and others, when he cuts.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the cutter and user is quite different from what he uses in cutting?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in the same way what the harper uses in harping will be different from the harper himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, that is what I was asking just now—whether the user and what he uses are always, in your opinion, two different things.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what are we to say of the shoemaker? Does he cut with his tools only, or with his hands as well?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: With his hands as well.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So he uses these also?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Does he use his eyes, too, in his shoe-making?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we admit that the user and what he uses are different things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the shoemaker and the harper are different from the hands and eyes that they use for their work?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And man uses his whole body too?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we said that the user and what he uses are different?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So man is different from his own body?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then whatever is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Oh, but you can—that he is the user of the body.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the user of it must be the soul?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And ruler?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now, here is a remark from which no one, I think, can dissent.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That man must be one of three things.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What things?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Soul, body, or both together as one whole.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But yet we have admitted that what actually rules the body is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We have.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And does the body rule itself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because we have said that it is ruled.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then that cannot be what we are seeking.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, does the combination of the two rule the body, so that we are to regard this as man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Perhaps it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The unlikeliest thing in the world: for if one of the two does not share in the rule, it is quite inconceivable that the combination of the two can be ruling.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But since neither the body nor the combination of the two is man, we are reduced, I suppose, to this: either man is nothing at all, or if something, he turns out to be nothing else than soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Precisely so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, do you require some yet clearer proof that the soul is man?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I assure you: I think it is amply proved.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if it is tolerably, though not exactly, we are content; exact knowledge will be ours later, when we have discovered the thing that we passed over just now because it would involve much consideration.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The point suggested in that remark a moment ago,Cf. Plat. Alc. 1.129b. that we should first consider the same-in-itself; but so far, instead of the same, we have been considering what each single thing is in itself. And perhaps we shall be satisfied with that: for surely we cannot say that anything has more absolute possession of ourselves than the soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it is proper to take the view that you and I are conversing with each other, while we make use of words, by intercourse of soul with soul?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, that is just what we suggested a little while ago—that Socrates, in using words to talk with Alcibiades, is holding speech, not with your face, it would seem, but with Alcibiades—that is, with his soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then he who enjoins a knowledge of oneself bids us become acquainted with the soul.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And anyone who gets to know something belonging to the body knows the things that are his, but not himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then no physician, in so far as he is a physician, knows himself, nor does any trainer, in so far as he is a trainer.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It seems not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And farmers, and craftsmen generally, are far from knowing themselves. For these people, it would seem, do not even know their own things, but only things still more remote than their own things, in respect of the arts which they follow; since they know but the things of the body, with which it is tended.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So if knowing oneself is temperance, none of these people is temperate in respect of his art.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: None, I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that is why these arts are held to be sordid, and no acquirements for a good man.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then once again, whoever tends his body tends his own things, but not himself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It looks rather like it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But whoever tends his money tends neither himself nor his own things, but only things yet more remote than his own things?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So that the money-maker has ceased to do his own business.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if anyone is found to be a lover of Alcibiades' body, he has fallen in love, not with Alcibiades, but with something belonging to Alcibiades?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Your lover is rather he who loves your soul?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: He must be, apparently, by our argument.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he who loves your body quits you, and is gone, as soon as its bloom is over?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whereas he who loves your soul will not quit you so long as it makes for what is better?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And I am he who does not quit you, but remains with you when your body's prime is over, and the rest have departed.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, and I am glad of it, Socrates, and hope you will not go.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you must endeavor to be as handsome as you can.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, I shall endeavor.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You see how you stand: Alcibiades, the son of Cleinias, it seems, neither had nor has any lover except one only, and that a cherished one, Socrates, the son of Sophroniscus and Phaenarete.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you said that I only just anticipated you in coming to you, for otherwise you would have come to me first for the purpose of inquiring why I am the only one who does not leave you?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, that was so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the reason was that I was the only lover of you, whereas the rest were lovers of what is yours; and that is losing its charm, while you are beginning to bloom. So now, if you are not blighted and deformed by the Athenian people, I shall never forsake you. For my chiefest fear is of your being blighted by becoming a lover of the people, since many a good Athenian has come to that ere now. For fair of face is “the people of great-hearted Erechtheus;”Hom. Il. 2.547 but you should get a view of it stripped: so take the precaution that I recommend.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Exercise yourself first, my wonderful friend, in learning what you ought to know before entering on politics; you must wait till you have learnt, in order that you may be armed with an antidote and so come to no harm.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Your advice seems to me good, Socrates; but try to explain in what way we can take pains over ourselves.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, we have made one step in advance; for there is a pretty fair agreement now as to what we are, whereas we were afraid we might fail of this and take pains, without knowing it, over something other than ourselves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the next step, we see, is to take care of the soul, and look to that.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: While handing over to others the care of our bodies and our coffers.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then how shall we obtain the most certain knowledge of it? For if we know that, it seems we shall know ourselves also. In Heaven's name, do we fail to comprehend the wise words of the Delphic inscription, which we mentioned just now?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: With what intent do you say that, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will tell you what I suspect to be the real advice which the inscription gives us. I rather think there are not many illustrations of it to be found, but only in the case of sight.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Consider in your turn: suppose that, instead of speaking to a man, it said to the eye of one of us, as a piece of advice “See thyself,” how should we apprehend the meaning of the admonition? Would it not be, that the eye should look at that by looking at which it would see itself?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Clearly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us think what object there is anywhere, by looking at which we can see both it and ourselves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Why, clearly, Socrates, mirrors and things of that sort.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Quite right. And there is also something of that sort in the eye that we see with?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And have you observed that the face of the person who looks into another's eye is shown in the optic confronting him, as in a mirror, and we call this the pupil,The Greek ko/rh and the Latin “pupilla” both mean “little girl” or “doll,” and were used to indicate the dark center of the eye in which a tiny image can be seen reflected. for in a sort it is an image of the person looking?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then an eye viewing another eye, and looking at the most perfect part of it, the thing wherewith it sees, will thus see itself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if it looks at any other thing in man or at anything in nature but what resembles this,i.e. it must look at the pupil of a man's eye, or at what is comparable to that “perfect part” in other things. it will not see itself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if an eye is to see itself, it must look at an eye, and at that region of the eye in which the virtue of an eye is found to occur; and this, I presume, is sight.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if the soul too, my dear Alcibiades, is to know herself, she must surely look at a soul, and especially at that region of it in which occurs the virtue of a soul—wisdom, and at any other part of a soul which resembles this?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I agree, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can we find any part of the soul that we can call more divine than this, which is the seat of knowledge and thought?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: We cannot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this part of her resembles God, and whoever looks at this, and comes to know all that is divine, will gain thereby the best knowledge of himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And self-knowledge we admitted to be temperance.Above, Plat. Alc. 1.131b.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So if we have no knowledge of ourselves and no temperance, shall we be able to know our own belongings, good or evil?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How can that be, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For I expect it seems impossible to you that without knowing Alcibiades you should know that the belongings of Alcibiades are in fact his.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible indeed, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor could we know that our belongings are ours if we did not even know ourselves?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How could we?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so, if we did not so much as know our belongings, we could not know the belongings of our belongings either?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we were not quite correct in admitting just now that there are people who, without knowing themselves, know their belongings, while others know their belongings' belongings. For it seems to be the function of one man and one art to discern all three— himself, his belongings, and the belongings of his belongings.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It looks like it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And anyone who is ignorant of his belongings will be similarly ignorant, I suppose, of the belongings of others.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Quite so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if ignorant of others' affairs, he will be ignorant also of the affairs of states.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: He must be.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then such a man can never be a statesman.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, nor an economist either.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Nor will he know what he is doing.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, I agree.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And will not he who does not know make mistakes?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when he makes mistakes, will he not do ill both in private and in public?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And doing ill he will be wretched?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, very.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what of those for whom he is doing so?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: They will be wretched also.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is impossible to be happy if one is not temperate and good.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So it is the bad men who are wretched.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes, very.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And hence it is not he who has made himself rich that is relieved of wretchedness, but he who has made himself temperate.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So it is not walls or warships or arsenals that cities need, Alcibiades, if they are to be happy, nor numbers, nor size, without virtue.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if you are to manage the city's affairs properly and honorably, you must impart virtue to the citizens.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But could one possibly impart a thing that one had not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: How, indeed?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you or anyone else who is to be governor and curator, not merely of himself and his belongings in private, but of the state and its affairs, must first acquire virtue himself.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Hence it is not licence or authority for doing what one pleases that you have to secure to yourself or the state, but justice and temperance.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For you and the state, if you act justly and temperately, will act so as to please God.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Naturally.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And, as we were saying in what went before, you will act with your eyes turned on what is divine and bright.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, and looking thereon you will behold and know both yourselves and your good.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And so you will act aright and well?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well now, if you act in this way, I am ready to warrant that you must be happy.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: And I can rely on your warranty.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if you act unjustly, with your eyes on the godless and dark, the probability is that your acts will resemble these through your ignorance of yourselves.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is probable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For if a man, my dear Alcibiades, is at liberty to do what he pleases, but is lacking in mind, what is the probable result to him personally, or to the state as well? For instance, if he is sick and at liberty to do what he pleases—without a medical mind, but with a despot's power which prevents anyone from even reproving him—what will be the result? Will not his health, in all likelihood, be shattered?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Again, in a ship, if a man were at liberty to do what he chose, but were devoid of mind and excellence in navigation, do you perceive what must happen to him and his fellow-sailors?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do: they must all perish.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And in just the same way, if a state, or any office or authority, is lacking in excellence or virtue, it will be overtaken by failure?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: It must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it is not despotic power, my admirable Alcibiades, that you ought to secure either to yourself or to the state, if you would be happy, but virtue.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And before getting virtue, to be governed by a superior is better than to govern, for a man as well as a child.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the better is also nobler?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the nobler more becoming?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then it becomes a bad man to be a slave, since it is better.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So vice is a thing that becomes a slave.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And virtue becomes a free man.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we should shun, my good friend, all slavishness?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Most certainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you now perceive how you stand? Are you on the side of the free, or not?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I think I perceive only too clearly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do you know how you may escape from the condition in which you now find yourself? Let us not give it a name, where a handsome person is concerned!

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: If it be your wish, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That is not well said, Alcibiades.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, what should I say?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: If it be God's will.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Then I say it. And yet I say this besides, that we are like to make a change in our parts, Socrates, so that I shall have yours and you mine. For from this day onward it must be the case that I am your attendant, and you have me always in attendance on you.paidagwgei=n is used here simply in the sense of “following about as personal attendant.”

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Ah, generous friend! So my love will be just like a stork; for after hatching a winged love in you it is to be cherished in return by its nestling.It was commonly believed that aged storks were fed by younger storks which they had previously hatched and reared.

sp.speaker: Alcibiades
sp.p: Well, that is the position, and I shall begin here and now to take pains over justice.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I should like to think you will continue to do so; yet I am apprehensive, not from any distrust of your nature, but in view of the might of the state, lest it overcome both me and you.
